subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: Text Conversion
msgSnippet: Chuck: Getting more texts transliterated into QS is probably the best thing we can do for improving the group s ability to read QS next to writing back and
messageBody:
Chuck:

Getting more texts transliterated into QS is probably the best thing we can do for  improving the group's ability to read QS next to writing back and forth to each other in it.  When I first started using QS, I corresponded with other people, in particular with a gentleman from New Zealand, and it was very interesting to hear his dialect come through his writing.  It caused me no difficulty in reading.  At worst, it might cause a slight slowing of reading speed when encountering the occasional word spelt differently than the way I would have spelt it.

Paige G.

Chuck Peck wrote:

Hello All,

I agree completely with you about not creating a
?universal? dialect. I have in a number of messages
stated that it?s SQ?s phonic abilities that allows it
to show a speaker?s/writer?s accent/dialect. I have
written regular postal mail with a number of people
from this group and it?s both interesting and
enlightening to hear their accent come out in their
writing with QS.

My intent when I created the dictionary and the
up-coming conversions is to give the community
something to compare to and something to read. I
believe that if you do not get enough reading of QS
you will never read/understand it as fast as orthodox
characters.

Chuck

--- fctarbox3 <rtarbox@...> wrote:
> Be careful using the dictionaries on this group.
> They're very
> susceptible to regional accent.  I'd also like to
> refer you to
>
http://groups.yahoo.com/group/Read_Alphabet/message/292
> , where I
> verbosely and antagonistically suggest a rather
> large and extensive
> project for creating a "universal" dialect of
> quickscript that
> sacrifices regional variation in favor of
> legibility.
>
> --- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Chuck Peck
> <chuck091956@y...>
> wrote:
> > Hello All,
> >
> > I'm in the process of building a Perl Script to
> convert Orthodox
> character text files into QuickScript ones. It will
> use the database
> that generated the dictionary that is in the Files
> section. I'm
> currently working on the grammar/phonics rules that
> will try to
> convert works not in the database into their phonic
> equivalent. I
> think I have someone who will convert the formatted
> MS Word docs
> into Adobe PDF for me.
> >
> > Once its done... hopefully sometime next month,
> I'm going to start
> converting some of the Gutenberg classic text pieces
> into QS. If
> anyone has any recommendations of writings they'd
> like to see in QS
> please let me know.
> >
> > I'll update the group as I get closer to
> completing it.
> >
> >
> > Chuck
> >
> >
> >
> > ---------------------------------
> > Do you Yahoo!?
> > SBC Yahoo! DSL - Now only $29.95 per month!
>
>

back and forth to each other in it.  When I first started using QS,
I corresponded with other people, in particular with a gentleman from New
Zealand, and it was very interesting to hear his dialect come through his
writing.  It caused me no difficulty in reading.  At worst, it
might cause a slight slowing of reading speed when encountering the occasional
word spelt differently than the way I would have spelt it.
<p>Paige G.
